Author: Nicole Forsgren, Jez Humble, Gene Kim

Author: Will Larson

Author: James Clear

Title: Beyond the Goal: Eliyahu Goldratt Speaks on the Theory of Constraints
Author: Eliyahu Goldratt
Summary: A lecture series by Goldratt reflecting on Theory of Constraints since The Goal
Why recommended: Recording on CDs (!!) or Audible audiobook.

Title: Boundaries for Leaders: Results, Relationships, and Being Ridiculously in Charge
Author: Henry Cloud

Title: Bursts: The Hidden Pattern Behind Everything We Do
Author: Albert-László Barabási

Title: Capitalism without Capital: The Rise of the Intangible Economy
Author: Jonathan Haskel, Stian Westlake
Summary: Explores where value is created and preserved in software and data driven markets and companies.

Title: Domain Driven Design: Tackling Complexity in the Heart of Software
Author: Eric Evans

Title: Emergent Strategy: Shaping Change, Changing Worlds
Author: Adrienne Maree Brown

Title: Good Strategy / Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Richard Rumelt

Title: Governing the Commons: The Evolution of Institutions for Collective Action
Author: Elinor Ostrom
Summary: Explores how common-pool resources (resources that are rival and subtractable, such as irrigation systems or grazing lands) can be successfully managed by the people who use them, rather than being controlled by the state or private interests. Ostrom argues that such resources can be effectively managed through the creation of rules that are developed and enforced by the users themselves, avoiding a Tragedy of the Commons.
Why recommended: This applies not only to concrete resources like natural resources but also to abstract resources within a company: shared architecture, naming/nomenclature, common schemas, scheduling, prioritization, or the lack of any of these. The rules Ostrom present a way to effectively manage and protect these resources without falling into the perpetual struggle between top-down vs bottom-up.

Title: Grit: The Power of Passion and Perseverance
Author: Angela Duckworth

Title: It's Not Luck: Marketing, Production, and the Theory of Constraints
Author: Eliyahu Goldratt
Summary: The first description of the Theory of Constraints Thinking Process (later to be The Logical Thinking Process / ToC LTP)
Why recommended: A follow-on fictional book narratively picking up where The Goal left off. This book shows the Thinking Process / Logical Thinking Process in its earliest stages, primarily focused on Evaporating Clouds (later called Conflict Resolution Diagrams) and Current Reality Trees (later called Problem trees).

Title: Nudge: The Final Edition

Title: Outcomes over Output: Why Customer Behavior is the Key Metric for Business Success
Author: Joshua Seiden

Author: DeMarco & Lister

Author: Geoffrey G. Parker, Marshall W. Van Alstyne, Sangeet Paul Choudary

Title: Project to Product: How to Survive and Thrive in the Age of Digital Disruption with the Flow Framework
Author: Mik Kersten

Author: Grosse & Loftness

Author: Matthew Skelton, Manuel Pais

Author: Joseph O'Connor

Title: The Book of Why:  The New Science of Cause and Effect
Author: Judea Pearl

Title: The Fifth Discipline: The Art and Practice of the Learning Organization
Author: Peter Senge

Title: The Goal: A Process for Ongoing Improvement
Author: Eliyahu Goldratt
Summary: The original description of the Theory of Constraints
Why recommended: A fictional book that Socratically describes the Theory of Constraints in narrative form. Excellently shares the fundamentals in a way that subsequent books have not captured. Not a practitioners book but lays the ground work. Gene Kim's The Phoenix Project was based on this book in style and the Theory of Constraints, generally.

Title: The Infinite Game: How Great Businesses Achieve Long-lasting Success
Author: Simon Sinek

Title: The Innovator's Dilemma: When New Technologies Cause Great Firms to Fail (Management of Innovation and Change)
Author: Clayton M. Christensen

Title: The Logical Thinking Process - An Executive Summary
Author: H. William Dettmer

Title: The Logical Thinking Process: A Systems Approach to Complex Problem Solving
Author: H. William Dettmer
Summary: An up-to-date, approachable and practical guide to the ToC LTP
Why recommended: Dettmer's collection and refinement of the Theory of Constraints Thinking Process. These are a set of systems thinking tools that allow for diagnosis, strategy and planning within a complex system such as an organization, a project or even an individual. ToC LTP tools are even applied to psychology.

Title: The Minto Pyramid Principle: Logic in Writing, Thinking and Problem Solving
Author: Barbara Minto
Summary: How to structure your thinking, writing and problems solving logically.
Why recommended: This version ("The Minto Pyramid Principle") is more expensive and harder to get than her earlier book "The Pyramid Principle" which does not cover problem solving. I recommend this later book but if you're not interested in spending as much, you'll get much of the value out of her earlier book.

Title: The Mythical Man Month: Essays on Software Engineering
Author: Fred Brooks

Title: The Phoenix Project: A Novel about IT, DevOps, and Helping Your Business Win
Author: Gene Kim, Kevin Behr, George Spafford

Title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
Author: Charles Duhigg

Title: The Pyramid Principle: Logic in Writing 3rd ed.
Author: Barbara Minto

Title: The Three Rules: How Exceptional Companies Think
Author: Mumtaz Ahmed, Michael E. Raynor

Title: The Unicorn Project: A Novel About Developers, Digital Disruption, and Thriving in the Age of Data
Author: Gene Kim

Title: Thinking for a Change: Putting the ToC Thinking Process to Use
Author: Lisa J. Scheinkopf
Summary: A practical guide to Theory of Constraints (ToC).
Why recommended: It's a dry read but considered one of the three foundational books of ToC and is more practical than Goldratt's The Goal (the original description of ToC). I may remove this if H. William Dettmer's book The Logical Thinking Process (which is the third of these books) is better. (I haven't read it yet.)

Title: Thinking in Systems: A Primer
Author: Donella Meadows

Title: Turn the Ship Around!: A True Story of Turning Followers into Leaders
Author: L. David Marquet
